hundred different variables in there there's all sorts of things like number of butterflies per square meter and all that kind of stuff so you've got all
these different variables and then we also run this model over and over and over and over so this is something called ensemble weather forecasting so
because the weather is such a chaotic system a tiny little variation in your starting
parameters can end up with a totally different result in your weather model and because there's always margins of error on the
kind of measurements that we take before we run the model we kind of perturb the measurements within that margin of error
and then run it maybe 30 times so we'll get 30 different results from
the same starting point and then if some of the quite a lot of those are kind of clustering and and you get a lot of
results that are agreeing with each other will have more confident more confidence in that forecast or as if
they're all kind of more spread out then we'll have lower confidence and it's how we can issue probabilities and that kind of information so this is just even more
